summary: dengue disease may present as a nonspecific febrile illness or as a more severe infection marked by hemorrhage or circulatory failure. deNV is a flavivirus that exists as 4 distinct serotypes (DENV-1–DENV-4) and is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes (5). peripheral blood mononuclear cells from healthy blood donors can be used to generate monocyte-derived DCs. these cells can be productively infected with DENV and are the primary human ex vivo model for studying primary DENV infections. a comprehensive functional analysis comparing DC infections with DENV-2 and its most phylogenetically distant serotype, DENV-4. we show that DENV-2 and DENV-4 display different replication strategies and induce different antiviral innate immune responses in human DCs. this may be related to differences in viral fitness, transmission, and pathogenesis. DCs infected with DENV-2 showed significantly higher levels of DENV nonstructural 3 (NS3) protein (Figure 1C) at 48 and 72 hpi compared with the DCs infected with DENV-4. together, these data suggest that DENV-2 infects fewer DCs later during infection, with each infected cell producing many infectious particles. paired, 2-tailed Wilcoxon signed-rank test compared DENV-4 to DENV-2. asterisks represent statistical significance for either DENV-2 or DENV-4 compared with mock-infected cells at each time point. DCs infected with DENV-2 and DENV-4 did not demonstrate statistically significant differences in expression of cleaved caspase-3, a marker for apoptosis, or in levels of cell death. cellular marker positivity during mock, dengue virus 2 (DENV-2), and DENV-4 infections by autogating. the comparative effects on each marker were calculated as the log10 of the relative risk for positive marker frequency between the indicated infection conditions. the phenotypic landscape is different during DENV-2 versus DENV-4 infection in DCs. cells expressing high levels of DENV envelope (DENV E) protein were not limited to one phenotypic DC population. IL-8 expression was more broadly distributed but also largely colocalized to the same region of the viSNE plots. cells most highly expressing IP-10 did not correspond with DENV E–expressing cells. the responses to DENV infection were heterogeneous and there were distinct cellular phenotypes associated with cells expressing viral antigens. the previous data (Figures 2 and 3) revealed marked phenotype differences induced by DENV-2 and DENV-4 for the entire population of each DC sample. proinflammatory cytokines (TNF- and IL-1), chemokines (IL-8) and ISGs (IP-10) demonstrated distinct patterns of production in DENV-infected versus bystander DCs. both DENV-2– and DENV-4–infected DCs demonstrated higher percentages of cleaved caspase-3+ cells compared with their respective bystander cells at later time points. the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure was performed within each time point to adjust the significance level for multiple comparisons. bystander cells show distinct cytokine and cleaved caspase-3 phenotypes compared with infected cells during DENV infection. multiplex ELISAs were performed to evaluate extracellular cytokine secretion by DCs during DENV infection. in contrast, DENV-2 infection induced minimal IFN- and IP-10 secretion compared with mock and DENV-2 infection of DCs. deNV-4 infection also induced greater secretion of several proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines compared with mock infection. cytokine and chemokine production during DENV-2 and DENV-4 infection appears to be replication dependent. differences in cytokine and chemokine production could be due to the different proportion of infected cells in the culture between the two viruses. e and chemokine secretion depended less on viral load (MOI) and more on inherent strain differences between the two virus strains. we infected human donor-matched DCs with DENV-2 and DENV-4 (MOI of 0.5) the viral isolates used were representative of prevalent genotypes of the DENV-2 and DENV-4 serotypes. DENV-2 and DENV-4 demonstrate replication differences in human DCs but not in mosquito cells. mass cytometry by time-of-flight analysis of DCs infected with dengue virus 2 (DENV-2) and DENV-4. we observed comparable replication kinetics for DENV-2 and DENV-4 during a 5-day time course. the rapid peak and subsequent decline in titers for DENV-4 during DC infection was not observed in mosquito cells. these viruses have different replication kinetics, and presumably different viral fitness strategies, in human DCs but not in mosquito cells. DCs infected with DENV-2 and DENV-4 did not demonstrate statistically significant differences in expression of cleaved caspase-3, a marker for apoptosis, or in levels of cell death. compared cellular marker positivity during mock, dengue virus 2 (DENV-2), and DENV-4 infections by autogating. viSNE plots were generated using all 18 phenotypic markers used for mass cytometry by time-of-flight (CyTOF) staining except markers for dengue virus. each point in the plot represents a single cell, and the axes show arbitrary units based on the t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE) algorithm. a small number of cells expressing high levels of DENV E were visible but distributed throughout the viSNE plots. DC costimulatory markers CD80, CD86, and CD40 were notably upregulated during DENV-2 infection compared with mock treatment. this indicates that the cells upregulating cytokines are distinct from those upregulating high levels of DC maturation markers during DENV infection. DC activation markers CD80, CD86, CD40, and CCR7 were similarly upregulated by DENV-infected and bystander cells following both DENV-2 and DENV-4 infections. both DENV-2–infected and DENV-4–infected DCs showed increased production of TNF-+ and IL-1+ cells compared with their respective bystander cells. bystander cells show distinct cytokine and cleaved caspase-3 phenotypes compared with infected cells during DENV infection. bystander cells show similar DC surface marker phenotypes compared with infected cells during deNV infection. the cells were stratified as DENV-infected (I) cells (filled circles) or bystander (B) cells (open circles) the percentage of mock, bystander, or DENV-infected cells of DENV-2 (green) and DENV-4 samples stained positive intracellularly for the cytokines (A) TNF-, (B) IL-1, (C) IL-8, and (D) IP-10. IL-6, IL-1, IL-12, MIP-1, MIP-1, RANTES, and IL-8) compared with mock and DENV-2 infection. DENV-4 infection of DCs induces greater cytokine and chemokine secretion compared with DENV-2 infection. the observed differences in cytokine and chemokine production by DENV-2 and DENV-4 could be due to the different proportion of infected cells in the culture between the two viruses. cytokine and chemokine secretion for DENV-2 infection was generally MOI dependent, with greater cytokine and chemokine secretion at the higher MOI. this is the first study to utilize CyTOF to examine cells infected with a hemorrhagic fever virus. this is the first study to utilize CyTOF to examine cells infected with a hemorrhagic fever virus. this strain is also more capable of activating human DCs, upregulating DC migration markers, and inducing cytokine production compared with this DENV-2 strain. the most 5′ region of the DENV 3′ untranslated region is one of the least conserved regions of the DENV genome among the serotypes (46). the most 5′ region of the DENV 3′ untranslated region is one of the least conserved regions of the DENV genome among the serotypes (46) different DENV sfRNA species accumulate in vertebrate and invertebrate hosts during host change, with subsequent implications for innate immune induction and viral fitness. the viSNE analysis in this study is elucidating because it shows that the DCs producing the highest amount of cytokines are largely distinct from those upregulating the highest amount of DC activation markers during DENV infection. data also show that type I IFN is secreted at higher levels during DENV-4 infection of DCs as compared with DENV-2 infection of DCs. bystander cells should be unable to block IFN signaling, since they do not contain DENV NS5 protein, which degrades STAT2 in infected cells. cells undergoing apoptosis may release viral progeny, contributing to virus spreading, or may release apoptotic bodies later engulfed by other DCs. loss of DENV-infected DCs by apoptosis could impair the connection between innate and adaptive immunity and diminish the human immune response to DENV infection. both infected and bystander DCs are then able to migrate to draining lymph nodes and interact with T cells (57). bystander cells could also have been abortively infected or could have captured DENV antigens via phagocytosis of exosomes containing DENV antigens. aedes aegypti cells were cultured at 37°C in -MEM GlutaMAX. they were supplemented with 10% (v/v) FBS, 100 U/ml penicillin, 100 g/ml streptomycin, and 10 mM HEPES. these tissue culture reagents were purchased from Thermo Fisher Scientific. a prototypic DENV-2 strain belonging to the Asian I genotype (Supplemental Figure 2) that was isolated from a patient with dengue shock syndrome in Thailand in 1964. a DENV-4 strain belonging to genotype IIB (Supplemental Figure 1) that was isolated from a patient with dengue fever in Indonesia in 1976 (DENV-4 1036) were used in this study. a set of 10 primer pairs was designed based on the sequence of available DENV-4 complete genomes. each primer included the sequence of universal primers M13-fwd or M13-rev. RT-PCR was performed using the superscript III high-fidelity RT-PCR kit. removed and serial dilutions of virus supernatants in -MEM GlutaMAX were added to the wells. the cells were then incubated at 33°C and 5% CO2 for 2 hours. -stimulated factor (GM-CSF) (PeproTech), 1,000 U/ml human IL-4 (PeproTech) and 10% (v/v) Hyclone FBS (Thermo Fisher Scientific) for 5 days at 37°C and 5% CO2. donor-matched DCs were infected with DENV-2 or DENV-4 at an MOI of 0.5 or treated with UV-inactivated virus or DC medium (mock) for 60 minutes at 37 the data were acquired on the Luminex 100 System and were analyzed by a standard curve fit. for each analyte, a 7-point dilution series of the protein standard plus an assay diluent-only background well were run in duplicate. all antibodies were purchased preconjugated from Fluidigm or conjugated. all antibodies were either purchased preconjugated from Fluidigm or validated in-house using MaxPar X8 conjugation kits. barcoded samples were acquired on a CyTOF2 using a superSampler fluidics system (Victorian Airships) at an event rate of 350 events/s. data were concatenated and normalized using the CyTOF2 software. the data were then uploaded to Cytobank version 5.2.0 (Cytobank Inc.) for analysis. viSNE plots were generated using all 18 phenotypic markers from the CyTOF panel (Supplemental Table 1). deNV E and NS3 proteins were purposefully excluded as clustering parameters. significance was determined using a paired, 2-tailed Wilcoxon signed-rank test. autogating and manual gating strategies were determined to show grossly consistent patterns. markers were ordered vertically by a hierarchical clustering of the log10 relative risks for that marker and time point. cells were maintained in RPMI media (Invitrogen) supplemented with 8% (v/v) tryptose phosphate broth, 2 mM L-glutamine, 0.1 mM MEM nonessential amino acids (Sigma-Aldrich), 100 U/ml penicillin, 100 g/ml streptomycin, and 10% (v/v) FBS (all Thermo Fisher Scientific) at 28°C in a humidified atmosphere DENV-2 16681 (cDNA) and DENV-4 1036 (67) were used in this study. they were grown in C6/36 cells for 7 days as described elsewhere. UV-inactivated DENV-2 and DENV-4 were prepared by irradiating the virus with a UV lamp for 10 minutes. a selection of complete genomes of DENV-4 was downloaded from the NIAID Virus Pathogen Database and Analysis Resource. the selection was manually trimmed to contain 57 isolates representative of the complete genetic diversity. a consensus neighbor-joining phylogenetic tree from 1,000 replicates was obtained using the program Geneious. Genomes used were as follows: VietNam2/2006: EU482654; VietNam-N/A. deNV infectious particles were titrated by plaque assay using BHK cells and a standard protocol (65) the cells were seeded in 12-well plates (at 1 105 cells/well) and incubated overnight at 37°C with 5% CO2. the following day, the medium was removed and serial dilutions of virus supernatants in -MEM GlutaMAX were added. monocyte-derived DCs were generated from buffy coats of healthy donors. naive DCs were infected with deNV-2 or deNV-4 at an MOI of 0.5 or treated with UV-inactivated virus. subconfluent Aag2 cells cultured in 24-well plates were washed once in PBS 24 hours after seeding and then infected with DENV at an MOI of 0.5 in 200 l. after a 1-hour incubation at 28°C, the inoculum was removed and cells were washed once in PBS and then returned in Aag2 culture media to the 28°C incubator. the standard curve modeling was performed in R version 3.2.0 (73). Flow cytometry. mock- or DENV-infected DCs were first incubated in Human TruStain FcX (Biolegend), followed by incubation using the Live/Dead Fixable Blue Dead Cell Stain Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific), according to the manufacturer’s instructions. the samples were pooled to minimize staining variability, permeabilized using BD Cytofix/Cytoperm (BD Biosciences) and incubated with a 0.1-micron-filtered cocktail of MaxPar antibodies against intracellular antigens. the samples were then washed, incubated with 0.125 nM Ir nucleic acid intercalator to enable cell identification based on DNA content, and stored in PBS containing 2% freshly diluted formaldehy manual and automatic gating have comparative advantages and disadvantages. autogating may be subject to operator bias in choosing thresholds for marker positivity or negativity (76), whereas autogating is not subject to such bias, as it specifies a perfectly reproducible threshold for each channel. significance was determined using a paired, 2-tailed Wilcoxon signed-rank test. the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure was performed with R version 3.3.0. event counts for manually gated data were exported from Cytobank Inc. autogating was implemented using the flowCore (79) and flowStats (80) R packages from Bioconductor. primary human cells used in this work were obtained from buffy coats from the New York Blood Center.
